SEARCH
Package net.jnellis.interleave

Interface Interleaver

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractInterleaver, JosephusInterleaver, PermutationInterleaver, RecursiveInterleaver, SequenceInterleaver, ShufflePrimeInterleaver, SimpleInterleaver
public interface Interleaver
In place (in-memory) interleave a single collection or two collections, using a Faro Shuffle.

Interleaving a single collection chooses a midpoint then interleaves items from that midpoint with the beginning of the collection. 

 Ex. [1,2,3,4,a,b,c,d]  ->  [1,a,2,b,3,c,4,d]
Interleaving two collections swaps items between them. 
 Ex. [1,2,3,4] and [a,b,c,d]  ->  [1,a,2,b] and [3,c,4,d]

There are two types of interleaving: InShuffle and OutShuffle. The OutShuffle guarantees that the first item of the collection (or first collection) remains first and the last item of the collection (or second collection) remains last. The InShuffle leads with the middle of the collection or the second collections if there are two. 

 Example of OutShuffle [1,2,3,a,b,c]   -> [1,a,2,b,3,c]
                       [1,2,3] [a,b,c] -> [1,a,2] [b,3,c]
 
 Example of InShuffle [1,2,3,a,b,c]   -> [a,1,b,2,c,3]
                      [1,2,3] [a,b,c] -> [a,1,b] [2,c,3]

A folding interleave will shuffle items from the end of the collection instead of the midpoint, effectively folding the collection at the midpoint. 

 Example of Folding OutShuffle [1,2,3,a,b,c]   -> [1,c,2,b,3,a]
                               [1,2,3] [a,b,c] -> [1,c,2] [b,3,a]
 
 Example of Folding InShuffle [1,2,3,a,b,c]   -> [c,1,b,2,a,3]
                              [1,2,3] [a,b,c] -> [c,1,b] [2,a,3]

NOTE: Unintuitive behavior can arise when trying to interleave a single collection of odd length or two collections of unequal length. The follow examples describe behavior of each type of shuffle operation (Shuffle) with one and two collection interleaving:

In-Shuffle 

 one odd length collection
   Ex. [1,2,3,a,b,c,d] -> [a,1,b,2,c,3,d]
   EX. [1,2,3,4,a,b,c] -> [4,1,a,2,b,3,c] // unexpected behavior, at front!

 two unequal length collections
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,5], [a,b,c,d] -> [a,1,b,2,5], [c,3,d,4]
   Ex. [1,2,3,4], [a,b,c,d,e] -> [a,1,b,2], [c,3,d,4,e]

Out-Shuffle 

 one odd length collection
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,b,c,d] -> [1,a,2,b,3,c,4]
   Ex. [1,2,3,a,b,c,d] -> [1,b,2,c,3,d,a] // unexpected behavior, off by 1!

 two unequal length collections
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,5], [a,b,c,d] -> [1,a,2,b,5], [3,c,4,d]
   Ex. [1,2,3,4], [a,b,c,d,e] -> [1,a,2,b], [3,c,4,d,e]

Folding In-Shuffle 

 one odd length collection
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,c,b,a] -> [a,1,b,2,c,3,4]  // unexpected behavior, at end!
   Ex. [1,2,3,d,c,b,a] -> [a,1,b,2,c,3,d]

 two unequal length collections
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,5], [d,c,b,a] -> [a,1,b,2,5], [c,3,d,4]
   Ex. [1,2,3,4], [e,d,c,b,a] -> [a,1,b,2], [c,3,d,4,e]

Folding Out-Shuffle 

 one odd length collection
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,c,b,a] -> [1,a,2,b,3,c,4]
   Ex. [1,2,3,d,c,b,a] -> [1,a,2,b,3,c,d] // unexpected behavior, at end!

 two unequal length collections
   Ex. [1,2,3,4,5], [d,c,b,a] -> [1,a,2,b,5], [3,c,4,d]
   Ex. [1,2,3,4], [e,d,c,b,a] -> [1,a,2,b], [3,c,4,d,e]

    interleave(Object[] array, int from, int to, Shuffle shuffle)

    Performs interleaving of the midpoint of this array with the head of the array.

  • Method Details

    • interleave

      void interleave(List<?> list, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of the midpoint of this list with the head of the list.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Parameters:
      list - elements to be interleaved in-place. For performance, must implement RandomAccess
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - if the specified list or its list-iterator does not support the set operation.

    • interleave

      default void interleave(Object[] array, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of the midpoint of this array with the head of the array.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Parameters:
      array - elements to be interleaved in-place.
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.

    • interleave

      void interleave(Object[] array, int from, int to, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of the midpoint of this array section with the start of the array section.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Parameters:
      array - elements to be interleaved in-place.
      from - starting index
      to - ending index, exclusive
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.

    • interleave

      <T> void interleave(List<T> a, List<T> b, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of two lists.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Type Parameters:
      T - type of list element
      Parameters:
      a - elements of first list to be interleaved in-place. For performance, must implement RandomAccess
      b - elements of second list to be interleaved in-place. For performance, must implement RandomAccess
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - if the specified list(s) or its list-iterator does not support the set operation.

    • interleave

      default <T> void interleave(T[] a, T[] b, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of two arrays.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Type Parameters:
      T - type of array element
      Parameters:
      a - elements of first array to be interleaved in-place.
      b - elements of second array to be interleaved in-place.
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.
      Throws:
      ArrayStoreException - if an element in the a array could not be stored in the b array because of a type mismatch. If you require compile-time protection against such mistakes then an alternative is to add a type literal. For example: 
      
 Integer[] a = new Integer[]{1,3,5,7};
 String[] b = new String[]{"a", "b", "c", "d"};
 interleaver.interleave(a,b,Shuffle.OUT); // runtime ArrayStoreException
 interleaver.<Integer>interleave(a,b,Shuffle.OUT); // compile-time error

    • interleave

      <T> void interleave(T[] a, int fromA, int toA, T[] b, int fromB, int toB, Shuffle shuffle)
      Performs interleaving of two array sections.

      The exact behavior of the interleaving is dependent upon the shuffle type which is explained in the class description above.

      Type Parameters:
      T - type of array element
      Parameters:
      a - elements of first array section to be interleaved in-place.
      fromA - starting index of first array
      toA - ending index of first array, exclusive
      b - elements of second array section to be interleaved in-place.
      fromB - starting index of second array
      toB - ending index of second array, exclusive
      shuffle - A descriptor indicating the type of interleave operation.
      Throws:
      ArrayStoreException - if an element in the a array could not be stored in the b array because of a type mismatch. If you require compile-time protection against such mistakes then an alternative is to add a type literal. For example: 
      
 Integer[] a = new Integer[]{1,3,5,7};
 String[] b = new String[]{"a", "b", "c", "d"};
 interleaver.interleave(a,b,Shuffle.OUT); // runtime ArrayStoreException
 interleaver.<Integer>interleave(a,b,Shuffle.OUT); // compile-time error
